SPIFFE/SPIRE identity lifecycle — issuance, rotation, revocation, workspace boundaries
description: SPIFFE defines SVIDs as verifiable identity documents for workloads. With mTLS via SPIFFE/SPIRE planned for robotics transports, identity lifecycle needs tracking. title: Add DevContainer configuration for reproducible dev environment
description: No .devcontainer/ configuration exists despite requiring specific Node toolchain and multi-service dependency stack. A DevContainer is high-leverage DX: makes works on my machine substantially less likely. Deliverables: devcontainer.json with correct Node version, Compose integration (auto-start dependency services), recommended VS Code extensions, post-create commands for setup.

title: Design approval state machine (lifecycle transitions)
description:
Define and implement the approval lifecycle state machine governing how approval requests transition through their lifecycle.

States: open → assigned → under_review → decided (approved | denied | changes_requested) → executed | rolled_back | expired

Requirements:
- Formal state machine with explicit transition guards (e.g., cannot approve if SoD violation, cannot transition to executed without all required approvals)
- Support for composite decisions: N-of-M approvals, sequential approval chains, specialist-required gates
- "Request changes" as a first-class state (blocks progress until addressed, like GitHub PR reviews)
- Escalation transitions: handoff to another approver ("needs review by X")
- Timeout/SLA-driven transitions (auto-escalate, auto-expire)
- Each transition produces a domain event (ApprovalOpened, ApprovalAssigned, DecisionRecorded, ApprovalExecuted, etc.)
- Transitions must be deterministic and auditable

title: API versioning strategy — compatibility rules + deprecation policy
description:
The OpenAPI v1 contract is positioned as source of truth and is "defined and evolving." For tooling (docs generation, client generation, testing) to work smoothly, the project needs explicit compatibility rules and deprecation policy.

Define:
- What constitutes a breaking change vs. backward-compatible evolution
- Versioning scheme for API, event schemas, and deployment charts
- CI checks that enforce compatibility (e.g., spectral lint, breaking-change detection on OpenAPI diffs)
- Deprecation timeline and communication mechanism
- How clients discover supported versions

This prevents "the API changed and all clients broke" as Portarium reaches real consumers.

title: Add SECURITY.md + enable private vulnerability reporting
description:
Standard expectation for public infrastructure projects. GitHub supports both a SECURITY.md policy file and private vulnerability reporting flows (orthogonal features, often used together).

SECURITY.md should include:
- Supported versions and which receive security patches
- How to report vulnerabilities (private reporting preferred)
- Expected response timeline
- Disclosure policy

Also enable GitHub's private vulnerability reporting feature on the repository.

Low effort, high trust signal. Required for OpenSSF badge eligibility.

title: Design embedded/streaming approval API for off-platform surfaces
description:
Design the API and interaction model for approvals that happen outside the main Portarium cockpit UI — in chat (Slack/Teams), mobile, dashboards, email, or other embedded contexts.

Requirements:
- Compact approval card format suitable for embedding (approve/reject buttons + summary)
- Off-platform actions bind to the same immutable approval payload snapshot
- Off-platform decisions write the same evidence/audit logs as in-UI decisions
- Same policy enforcement: SoD, N-of-M, specialist requirements apply regardless of channel
- Identity verification: approver identity must be verified even in embedded contexts (no "anyone with the link can approve")
- Webhook/event-driven: approval requests can push to external channels, decisions flow back

Channel-specific considerations:
- Chat (Slack/Teams): interactive message components with approve/reject/details buttons
- Mobile: push notification with quick-approve for low-risk, deep-link to cockpit for high-risk
- Email: structured email with approve/reject links (token-authenticated, single-use)
- Dashboard widgets: embeddable approval queue component

Security constraint: off-platform approval channels must never weaken the governance model — they are convenience layers, not bypass paths.

title: Implement review mode (deep inspection UX)
description:
Build the review mode for deep, deliberate inspection of high-risk or ambiguous approval requests. This is the counterpart to triage mode — optimised for careful decision-making.

Requirements:
- Full-page detail view rendering all evidence blocks from the block-based DSL
- Domain-specific renderer displayed prominently (diff view, preview, simulation output)
- Side panel or tabs for: policy evaluation results, prior decisions, comments/discussion, audit trail
- Inline commenting on specific evidence blocks (like GitHub PR line comments)
- Diff navigation: jump between changes, expand/collapse context
- Simulation re-run capability (if applicable): "show me what this would do now"
- Comparison view: side-by-side before/after for asset changes
- Decision panel: approve/deny/request-changes with structured rationale input
- "Request changes" creates actionable items linked back to specific evidence blocks
- Show who else needs to approve (N-of-M progress indicator)
- Escalation: handoff to another approver with context

title: AI risk controls framework — lightweight NIST AI RMF adoption
description: NIST AI Risk Management Framework helps manage risks of AI systems. Deliverables: risk taxonomy for Portarium AI features (advisor, RAG, evidence summarisation), trust boundary docs (what decisions AI can influence vs require human override), bias/fairness considerations, monitoring (recommendation accuracy, false positive/negative rates), incident response for bad AI advice leading to wrong approvals, auditor documentation. Governance artefact that shapes design constraints.

title: PDB validation + maintenance runbook
description:
PodDisruptionBudgets protect against voluntary disruptions but have sharp edges: they protect against voluntary evictions (not node failure), and overly strict budgets can block node drain indefinitely.

Deliverables:
- PDB configurations for control plane and worker
- Validation that PDBs don't block node drain under realistic maintenance scenarios
- Maintenance runbook: rolling upgrades, node drain, cluster upgrades with PDBs
- DR drill integration: PDB behaviour tested in drills, not only configured

title: Implement separation of duties and maker-checker enforcement
description:
Implement the governance primitives that control who is eligible to approve what, enforcing separation of duties at the domain/application layer.

Patterns to support:
- Maker-checker: requestor ≠ approver (prevent self-approval)
- N-of-M approvals: require N approvals from a pool of M eligible approvers for high-risk actions
- Specialist approval: require specific role/team approval based on what is changing (e.g., "data-platform team must approve SQL changes", analogous to GitHub CODEOWNERS / file-pattern reviewers)
- Role/authority mapping: clear mapping of who can approve what, queryable at approval-creation time

Implementation:
- Policy inputs: approval payload kind, risk score, affected resources, resource ownership, data classification
- Approver eligibility resolver: given payload + policy, return eligible approvers and why each is required
- SoD violation detector: prevent bypass by alternate channels (embedded approvals must enforce same rules)
- Durable identity attribution: approver identity must be cryptographically bound to decision

The UI must always expose: who is eligible to approve, why this approver is required, and what rule/policy is being satisfied or violated.

title: Design immutable approval payload domain model
description:
Define the core domain types for the approval payload — the immutable snapshot of "what was proposed" at the moment the approval request was created. This is the foundational contract the entire approval system builds on.

Must include:
- ApprovalRequest aggregate with immutable payload (diffs, previews, simulation outputs, policy evaluation at request time)
- ApprovalState value object (mutable): assignment, queue status, decisions, comments, escalation
- Decision value object: structured outcome (approve | deny | request_changes), rationale (required for deny/request-changes), timestamp, approver identity
- Payload content-type discriminator (kind field) to drive renderer selection
- Evidence attachment references (by hash/ID, not inline content)
- Branded domain primitives: ApprovalId, PayloadHash, DecisionId, etc.

Constraints:
- Domain code in src/domain/ — zero external dependencies
- Payload must be content-addressable (hash-verified) so approvers know they approved exactly what executed
- Support for multi-decision workflows (N-of-M, sequential approvals)

title: Add LICENSE file — release gate prerequisite
description:
The repo README states "all rights reserved until LICENSE file exists." This is the single most blocking artefact for open-source behaviour. Without a licence, no one can legally use, modify, or redistribute Portarium — which also blocks contribution posture, ecosystem adoption, and OpenSSF badge work.

Must decide on licence type (Apache-2.0, MIT, AGPL-3.0, BSL, etc.) and add the LICENSE file to repo root. This is a release gate, not a later administrative tidy-up.

Acceptance: LICENSE file committed, README updated to reference it, "all rights reserved" caveat removed.

title: Trace-context propagation + correlation model across all services
description: OpenTelemetry supports correlation across traces, metrics, and logs when telemetry shares consistent attributes. Define trace-context propagation spanning: Cockpit UI to API (W3C trace-context), API to Temporal workflow, workflow to adapter execution, CloudEvents emission (traceparent extension), approval creation/decision (linked spans), evidence ingestion. Goal: auditor can navigate from cockpit action to exact downstream side effects via a single trace ID.

title: Local governed-run smoke test — approval gate to adapter to machine to evidence
description: Validates the full product story locally. A single script that exercises: create workspace, register adapter+machine, define policy+workflow, start a governed run, hit an approval gate, approve it, execute via adapter, produce evidence, verify evidence chain. This is the credible demo and developer onboarding scenario. Must run against the local seeded stack (depends on bead-0733). Acceptance: one command produces a complete governed run with evidence viewable in cockpit.

title: Approval Workflows — Universal Decision Surface
description:
Portarium's governance-first architecture makes approvals the universal choke-point where humans reassert intent, accountability, and risk ownership. This epic covers the full approval system: a stable "approval shell" (queues, identity, policy context, decision capture, evidence) plus a pluggable "payload presentation" layer (diffs, previews, simulations, side-by-side comparisons, attachments, model explanations).

Key product thesis: the approvals experience is Portarium's "single pane of accountability" — a UX container supporting many payload types while staying consistent, fast, safe, and auditable.

Design constraints (non-negotiable):
- Approvals bind to immutable snapshots (the thing approved cannot silently change)
- Custom views are deterministic renderings of evidence, not arbitrary agent-defined UI
- Untrusted content is sanitised and constrained (CSP + encoding)
- Policy is explainable: UI shows why a policy triggered, in human terms
- Evidence-first: every run produces audit-worthy evidence

Reference domains: data ops, marketing assets, finance, software changes, robotic/agentic actions, demo generation.

title: Define SLIs/SLOs + error budget policy
description:
You cannot manage a service without defining what matters (SLIs), the target (SLOs), and what you do when you breach them. Existing beads mention "SLO dashboards + alerting" and "automated rollback on SLO breach" but skip the prerequisite: choosing SLIs, defining SLO windows, and adopting an error budget policy.

Without explicit SLOs, rollbacks devolve into ad hoc judgement calls.

Deliverables:
- SLI definitions for control plane (availability, latency p50/p95/p99, error rate)
- SLI definitions for worker (task completion rate, latency, retry rate)
- SLO targets with measurement windows (rolling 28-day, etc.)
- Error budget policy: what happens when budget is exhausted (freeze releases? reliability sprint?)
- Link SLOs to progressive delivery actions (canary promotion/rollback thresholds)

This is a hidden dependency — dashboards and alerts without SLO definitions are meaningless.

title: Multi-tenant infrastructure isolation — network policy, namespace, workload identity
description: Production multi-tenancy requires aligned isolation at infra layer. K8s multi-tenancy guidance: namespaces for isolation, network policy crucial (pod-to-pod traffic otherwise allowed and unencrypted). Deliverables: default-deny network policy, namespace isolation strategy (per-workspace vs shared), network egress allowlists, workload identity separation (workspace-scoped service accounts). Even without cluster-per-tenant, these patterns apply.

title: Evidence durability policy — retention, export, deletion, tamper-evidence
description: Audit-grade evidence properties often fail in storage details. Define: retention policy (how long, per workspace, per regulation), export capability (structured format for external audit), deletion policy (tenant offboarding), tamper-evidence/immutability posture (prove evidence not modified after capture), encryption at rest boundaries, backup and recovery. This is where audit narratives succeed or fail.

title: DDS-Security defaults enforcement — no harden-later for robotics
description: ROS 2 DDS-Security/SROS2: by default, DDS security features are NOT enabled. We'll harden later does not hold if early deployments establish insecure norms. Deliverables: DDS-Security enabled by default in all Portarium robotics transports (not opt-in), SROS2 tooling integration, secure DDS profile templates, test that unauthenticated DDS participant cannot join, migration path for insecure deployments.

title: Health probe semantics spec — liveness vs readiness vs backing stores
description:
Kubernetes probes are powerful but can cause cascading failures if misconfigured. The K8s docs explicitly caution that incorrect liveness probing can make systems less stable under load. The repo already exposes /healthz for both runtimes, but production probes need a spec.

Define:
- What "ready" means for control plane (DB connected? Event stream reachable? Auth provider reachable?)
- What "ready" means for worker (Temporal connected? Task queue registered?)
- What "live" means (process healthy? Not deadlocked?)
- How backing store failures (DB, Temporal, MinIO, Vault) affect probe responses
- Startup probe strategy (for slow-starting containers)
- Probe timeout/period/threshold tuning guidelines

Validate that probes under partial dependency failure don't cause cascading restarts.

title: Build renderer registry for domain-specific approval views
description:
Implement the renderer registry model that selects the best visual renderer for a given approval payload kind, with graceful fallback to generic rendering.

Architecture:
- Each approval payload has a kind (or contentType) and a set of evidence attachments/blocks
- Cockpit UI selects the best renderer available for that kind
- Fallback to generic renderer (effects list + attachments) when no specialised renderer exists

Renderer sources:
- First-party vertical packs: built into Portarium for core domains (data ops, marketing, finance, software, agentic actions)
- Tenant-approved extensions: tenant admin can enable curated renderers from a registry
- Agent-authored layouts: agents can choose which blocks to include and order them, but only from allow-listed block types

Renderers to build (initial set):
- Data operation renderer: table-level diff, record-level sample, JSON Patch, dry-run results
- Marketing asset renderer: side-by-side content comparison (before/after), asset preview (image/video)
- Finance renderer: amounts, accounts, payees, thresholds, invoices, approval chain
- Agent/robot action renderer: intent, tools/actions list, simulation output, expected writes
- Generic renderer: fallback for unknown payload kinds

Each renderer is a React component consuming typed block data — no access to raw approval internals.

title: Implement policy evaluation pipeline with explainability
description:
Build the policy-as-code evaluation pipeline that determines what approval gates apply to a given request, and provides human-readable explanations of why.

Requirements:
- Policy engine that evaluates structured approval inputs (payload kind, risk tags, resource ownership, data classification, blast radius)
- Produces structured results: pass / fail / needs_human, per-policy
- Explainability hooks: human-readable traces explaining why a policy triggered, linked to triggering evidence
- Responsibility mappings: ownership, required specialist approvers derived from policy
- Policy evaluation snapshot captured at approval-creation time (immutable, part of approval record)

Design considerations:
- Evaluate policies over structured inputs (Rego-like model or similar)
- Policies must be authorable/versionable (policy-as-code)
- UI must render: policy results, traces/explanations, links to inputs (diff blocks, effects blocks), responsibility mappings
- Goal: no "approvals as vibes" — every approval decision is grounded in policy + evidence

title: Fix docs/project-overview.md claim of one-command local compose
description: docs/project-overview.md describes deployment as one-command local compose for development, but the actual Compose baseline omits API and worker, and documented boot is multi-step. This documentation/expectation mismatch will confuse new contributors. Update docs to accurately reflect current state and link to the real local-first workflow once it exists.

title: Production Readiness Gaps — governance, release engineering, ops, tenancy, AI/robotics risk
description:
Tracks the missing work identified in the Portarium deep research review (2026-02-22). Covers gaps across:

1. Legal / open-source governance (LICENSE, SECURITY.md, OpenSSF)
2. Release engineering & supply chain integrity (SBOM, signing, versioning, Helm)
3. Operational readiness (SLI/SLO, health probes, PDBs, OIDC trust, observability correlation)
4. Tenancy isolation & data governance (evidence durability, RAG isolation, infra isolation)
5. AI/RAG risk controls (prompt injection, output validation, NIST AI RMF)
6. Robotics safety (DDS-Security defaults, semantic mapping, SPIFFE lifecycle)

Key finding: the roadmap is rich in capabilities and transport mechanisms, but domain-specific risk controls need to be tracked as concrete deliverables, not left as implicit "security hardening" at the end.

title: SBOM generation + artefact signing + provenance attestations
description:
Concrete supply-chain integrity deliverables that make SLSA mapping non-theoretical. Without these, "supply-chain guardrails" remains aspirational.

Deliverables:
- SBOM generation: produce CycloneDX or SPDX SBOM for each release artefact (control plane image, worker image, Helm chart)
- Container image signing: sign OCI images using cosign or similar
- Provenance attestations: generate and publish SLSA-style provenance for each build (who built, what source, what build system, what dependencies)
- Verification documentation: how consumers verify signatures and provenance
- CI integration: SBOM + signing + attestation steps added to release pipeline

This is what turns "we care about supply chain" into verifiable evidence.

title: Release unit definition — Helm charts, image build/push, promotion flows
description:
Define the explicit release unit that turns code into something deployable and testable under production-like constraints.

Deliverables:
- Helm charts for control plane and worker (parameterised for env-specific config)
- Image build + push pipeline (multi-arch, tagged with git SHA + semver)
- Promotion flow: dev → staging → production (with gates)
- Chart versioning aligned with API versioning strategy
- Release checklist / runbook

This is not just "infra" — it is the bridge between "code works locally" and "code is deployable."

title: Implement triage mode (rapid swipe-based approval UX)
description:
Build the "Tinder-style" triage mode for rapid classification and routing of approval requests. This is the high-throughput mode for processing approval queues quickly.

Requirements:
- Card-stack or swipeable interface showing approval summary cards
- Swipe/tap actions: Approve / Request Changes / Deny / Skip / Escalate
- Each card shows the approval shell summary (compact form)
- Contextual friction for high-risk approvals: swipe-to-approve disabled when risk is high or policy requires specialist — forces opening detail view
- Keyboard shortcuts for power users (a=approve, d=deny, r=request changes, s=skip)
- Queue management: filter by type, risk level, SLA urgency, assigned-to-me vs team
- Batch operations for homogeneous low-risk approvals (e.g., "approve all 12 staging deploys")

Safety guardrails:
- High-risk items require opening the detail view before deciding
- Policy-driven friction: require typed acknowledgement for certain categories
- Show prior decisions from other approvers
- Rationale required for deny/request-changes
- Visual risk indicators (color-coded risk bands)

title: Docker Compose profiles — baseline + runtime/auth/cockpit/tools profiles
description: Restructure docker-compose.yml into stable baseline (Postgres, Temporal, MinIO, Vault, OTel+Grafana, always-on) plus optional profiles: runtime (control plane + worker), auth (Keycloak/OpenFGA), cockpit (UI dev server), tools (extra debugging/admin). Docker Compose profiles are the intended mechanism for single-file multi-use-case service management. The current Compose explicitly omits API+worker; profiles solve this without breaking the baseline.

title: kind-based deployment smoke for infra parity
description: Optional extension for later. kind runs local Kubernetes clusters using Docker container nodes — useful for verifying infra/kubernetes manifests locally before pushing to real clusters. Deliverables: kind cluster config, script to deploy control plane + worker via Helm charts into kind, smoke test that exercises health endpoints and basic API calls in a real K8s environment. Lower priority than Compose-based DX but valuable for infra parity testing.

title: Robotics semantic mapping + safety invariants for VDA 5050 / MassRobotics
description: VDA 5050 defines AGV-to-master-control interface. MassRobotics AMR standard enables cross-manufacturer state sharing but is explicitly NOT a safety system. Missing: what do you trust from these feeds, what is advisory-only, what evidence is required before issuing physical commands? Deliverables: semantic mapping to Portarium domain, trust classification (trusted/advisory/untrusted), safety invariants before physical commands, evidence requirements, validation that rejects commands violating invariants.

title: Supported versions + patch cadence policy
description:
Define which versions receive security patches, how long they are supported, and what the expected patch cadence is. Ties directly into vulnerability handling and the vulnerability gate objective.

Deliverables:
- Supported versions table (in SECURITY.md and/or docs)
- Patch cadence commitment (e.g., critical CVEs within 48h, high within 1 week)
- End-of-life policy for old versions
- How fixes are disclosed (changelog, advisory, notification)

Matters for both users and contributors. Required for meaningful OpenSSF badge work.

title: Seed command — load canonical bundle into stores + optional evidence payloads
description: Convert existing canonical seed factories (src/domain/testing/canonical-seeds-v1.ts) into a runnable developer experience. Script that: selects a seed bundle, writes it into persistence stores (DB, MinIO), optionally provisions related state (policy/workflow entries, example approvals, evidence payloads). Exposed as npm run dev:seed. This is the bridge between strong domain test factories and a working local demo.

title: OCI images for API server + worker wired into Compose
description: Dockerfiles exist (infra/docker/control-plane.Dockerfile, infra/docker/worker.Dockerfile) but Compose does not run them by default. Wire images into Compose runtime profile, ensure env var parity with documented runtime-and-env.md surface, verify health endpoints work in containerised mode. This closes the gap between Dockerfiles exist and product is running in containers.

title: LLM security controls — output validation, prompt-injection resistance, agency boundaries
description: OWASP Top 10 for LLM Applications: prompt injection, insecure output handling, sensitive info disclosure, excessive agency, overreliance. Deliverables: output validation/sanitisation before cockpit rendering, prompt-injection resistance in RAG flows, hard agency boundaries (AI advisor recommend-only, never auto-approve), cross-workspace data leak prevention in AI responses, overreliance guardrails (low-confidence indicators), adversarial test suite.

title: CI-to-cloud OIDC trust policy hardening
description:
The infra plan includes OIDC federation for CI (GitHub Actions → cloud). Mis-scoped trust policies and missing claim constraints are frequent sources of pipeline fragility or over-privilege.

Deliverables:
- OIDC trust policy review: verify claim constraints (repo, branch, environment, workflow)
- Principle of least privilege for CI identity
- Document the trust boundary: what can a compromised CI workflow access?
- Test: verify workflow from a different branch/repo/org is rejected
- Audit trail: log OIDC token exchanges for CI operations

title: Build approval shell UI (stable container component)
description:
Implement the stable, consistent approval container UI that wraps all approval types. This is the "approval shell" — the consistent frame that every approval renders within, regardless of payload kind.

The shell must always answer at a glance:
- What is being approved? (type + short title + system of record)
- What will happen if approved? (high-level effects summary)
- Who is asking and why? (requestor/agent + objective)
- How risky is it? (risk score + why + blast radius indicator)
- What policy gates apply? (SoD/N-of-M/specialist requirements)
- What is the deadline? (SLA / operational urgency)
- What evidence exists? (attachments, diffs, previews, prior runs)

UX requirements:
- Card-based layout suitable for both list view and detail view
- Consistent action bar: Approve / Request Changes / Deny (with rationale input for negative outcomes)
- Prior decisions visible (who else has reviewed, what they decided)
- Escalation action: "needs review by X" handoff
- Responsive: works in cockpit sidebar, full-page, and embedded contexts
- Shell renders the selected domain renderer (from renderer registry) in its content area

title: RAG tenancy isolation model — workspace-scoped vector + graph retrieval
description: Vector and graph backends for RAG need explicit tenancy and auth models matching workspace boundaries. Decide: vector DB shards-per-workspace (stronger isolation) vs filters-per-workspace (simpler, leakage risk). Graph DB: multi-database per workspace vs shared graph with row-level security. Define authorisation unit for retrieval. Enforce isolation in storage layer, not only HTTP. Test: cross-workspace query must never return another workspace data.

title: OpenSSF Best Practices badge + SLSA provenance mapping
description:
Pursue the OpenSSF Best Practices Badge as a signal that Portarium follows established security and quality practices. The badge programme provides criteria and self-certification.

Prerequisites (must be done first):
- LICENSE file exists
- SECURITY.md exists
- Contribution norms documented

SLSA mapping work:
- Define build provenance generation (where, when, how artefacts are produced)
- Implement provenance attestations for release artefacts
- Document verification steps for consumers
- Map current CI/CD to SLSA levels and identify gaps

Note: this bead is blocked by LICENSE and SECURITY.md — without those, badge work is disconnected from real project readiness.

title: CI-to-cloud OIDC trust policy hardening
description: OIDC federation for CI (GitHub Actions to cloud). Mis-scoped trust policies and missing claim constraints cause pipeline fragility or over-privilege. Deliverables: trust policy review with claim constraints, least privilege CI identity, trust boundary documentation, rejection tests for wrong branch/repo/org, OIDC token exchange audit trail.

title: Implement evidence-first audit trail for approvals
description:
Build the evidence pipeline that ensures every approval interaction produces durable, auditable records. Every run must produce evidence you can audit — this is a core Portarium promise.

Evidence events to capture:
- approval_opened: who requested, what payload (hash), what policy evaluated to
- policy_evaluated: policy inputs, results, explanations, timestamp
- preview_generated: what was rendered for the approver, inputs used
- assigned: who was assigned, why (policy-driven or manual)
- decision_recorded: who decided, what they decided, rationale, what they saw (payload hash), timestamp
- run_unblocked: approval triggered downstream execution
- effects_applied: what actually happened post-approval
- rollback_executed: if rollback was needed, what was reverted

Requirements:
- Evidence objects are immutable, append-only
- Content-addressable: evidence references payload by hash so tampering is detectable
- Queryable: "show me everything that happened for approval X" timeline view
- Exportable: compliance teams can export evidence for external audit
- Linkage: evidence links to the exact approval payload snapshot, not mutable state
- Special handling for agent/robot requests: capture exactly what the human saw and decided

This is critical for regulated environments and for answering: "what did the human actually see and decide?"

title: Implement block-based presentation DSL for approval evidence
description:
Design and implement the typed block system that agents/workflows use to compose approval evidence. This is the "Notion-style blocks for approval evidence" concept — a strict schema-driven presentation layer that prevents arbitrary UI injection while enabling rich, domain-specific views.

Block types to implement:
- SummaryBlock: human-readable intent + objective + requestor
- PolicyBlock: SoD requirement, required approvers, policy explanations
- EffectsBlock: structured list of planned external effects (resources, operations, blast radius)
- DiffBlock: domain-specific diff rendering (table diff, JSON Patch, text tracked-changes)
- PreviewBlock: renderable output (image, PDF snapshot, MP4 demo, rendered HTML)
- SimulationBlock: dry-run output, predicted outcomes, rollback plan
- AIExplainBlock: model summary, confidence, key reasons + "show sources" links

Design constraints:
- Each block has a strict TypeScript schema; agents can only supply content matching the schema
- Blocks reference evidence payloads by hash/ID (content-addressable)
- Agents choose which blocks to include and in what order, but only from allow-listed set
- Agents can propose content but never execution (no arbitrary HTML/JS)
- Rendering is deterministic from block data — same data always produces same view
- JSON Patch (RFC 6902) as universal baseline for "what changed" representation

title: Implement security controls for agent-supplied approval content
description:
Implement the security boundary that prevents agents from injecting arbitrary UI/code through approval payloads while still allowing rich content presentation.

Threat model:
- Agents supply untrusted strings, rich text, URLs, images, videos
- Malicious or buggy agents could attempt XSS, data exfiltration, privilege escalation
- Agent-authored "layouts" could create misleading presentations that trick approvers

Security controls:
- Default to framework escaping + strict encoding/sanitisation for all agent-supplied content
- Restrict escape hatches: no direct DOM injection, no dangerouslySetInnerHTML for agent content
- Rich text sanitisation: allowlisted HTML tags/attributes only (no script, no event handlers)
- Strict Content Security Policy (CSP): reduce blast radius of any injection — no inline scripts, restricted connect-src
- URL validation: agent-supplied URLs must be allowlisted or proxied
- Image/media: proxy through Portarium CDN, no direct external loads (prevents tracking pixels, SSRF)
- Block schema validation: agent-supplied blocks must pass strict TypeScript schema validation before rendering
- Agents can propose content but never execution

Testing:
- XSS test suite against all block renderers with adversarial inputs
- CSP violation monitoring and alerting
- Fuzzing agent-supplied block content against schema validators

title: Local schema bootstrap — create tables/indexes + deterministic reset command
description: Local Postgres is running is not enough; you need guaranteed schema and deterministic reset. Deliverables: migration runner that applies all schema (tables, indexes, constraints) on first boot, reset command that drops and recreates (for dev iteration), idempotent apply (safe to re-run), integration with dev:seed workflow. Must work both for bare-metal Postgres and Compose-managed Postgres.

title: Local auth story — dev-only token mode or bundled OIDC/JWKS provider
description: Protected routes return 401 when auth config is absent, structurally preventing most API usage and Cockpit connection. Cockpit accepts bearer token via VITE_PORTARIUM_API_BEARER_TOKEN or localStorage. Options: (a) bundled Keycloak/Dex in Compose auth profile with pre-seeded users, or (b) dev-only token mode that bypasses JWKS validation in local dev. Either way, the local-first workflow must include how to mint or provide a token deterministically. This is a functional blocker for all real local API usage.

title: Local-First Developer Experience — one-command seeded stack
description:
Tracks the missing DX work to achieve a robust local-first developer experience. Currently Portarium supports a multi-step local run (Compose + separate runtime commands), but lacks:

- Single-command boot to "system usable" state
- Predictable persistence (schema present, data survives restarts, reset is explicit)
- Predictable auth (local OIDC or dev-only auth bypass)
- Smokeable E2E scenario (governed run producing evidence)

Existing bead-0733 covers the seed command itself; this epic covers the surrounding infrastructure (Compose profiles, auth, schema, DevContainer, smoke tests) that make bead-0733 actually work end-to-end.

Target: `npm run dev:all` → everything running, seeded, Cockpit connectable, one governed run demonstrable.
